introduction.p: Magnetic flux through a surface is a measure of number magnetic field lines that pass through the surface. You may recall from your study of electric flux that relative orientation of the surface and field is important for flux. For instance, if a field is parallel to a surface, there will be no flux, and if a field is perpendicular to the surface, it will have maximum flux as shown in .

figure.caption: Magnetic flux through a surface is largest when the surface is perpendicular to the magnetic field lines. In general, magnetic flux of a uniform magnetic field through flat surface of a loop is \Phi_B = BA\cos\theta. We write this in vector notation as \Phi_B = \vec B\cdot \vec A.

introduction.p: We denote magnetic flux of magnetic field \vec B by \Phi_B. Consider a open flat surface with area A. To take orientation of the surface, we introduce area vector \vec A which has magnitude A and direction normal to the surface.

sidebyside.p:
If \vec B is uniform, then flux of this field through the surface will be
\Phi_{B,\text{uniform}} \amp = \vec B \cdot \vec A. \amp = B A \cos\,\theta,
where \theta is angle between \vec B and \vec A.

In the general case of arbitrary field and arbitrary surface, we break the surface into small patches of flat areas, and apply Eq. to each patch. Summing over all patches gives us an estimate of the net flux through the surface. We can write this process as a formal sum.
\Phi_B \approx \sum_\text{patches} \vec B \cdot \Delta \vec A.

introduction.p:
In the limit of infinitesimally small patches, we get the exact flux, which we write as a conceptual integral.
\Phi_B = \int_\text{surface}\, \vec B \cdot d \vec A.

exercise.title: Flux of Constant Magnetic Field - Simple Surfaces

sidebyside.p: A constant magnetic field B_0\hat u_z is present in a region as shown in . Calculate magnetic flux through two flat surfaces of area A (a) in the xy-plane (surface S_1) and (b) in the xz-plane (surface S_2).

solution.p:
(a) The given magnetic field is pointed towards positive z axis. The normal to an area in the xy-plane is along the z axis. The unit vector normal to the xy-plane will be either +\hat u_z or -\hat u_z , which we can write as \pm\hat u_z . The magnetic flux is
\Phi_B \amp = \left( B_0\hat u_z \right) \cdot \left(\pm \hat u_z A\right) \amp =\pm B_0 A.

(b) The normal to the area in the xz-plane is \pm\hat u_y. The dot product between the magnetic field and the normal now equals zero. Therefore, the flux of the magnetic field pointed towards the positive z axis through an area in the xz-plane will be zero. A similar argument will show that the flux of the given magnetic field through an area in the yz-plane will also be zero.

exercise.title: Flux of Constant Magnetic Field - Slanted Surface

sidebyside.p: Given a constant magnetic field of magnitude B_0 in the positive z-axis direction find the magnetic flux through the rectangular surface PQRS inside the cube of side a as shown in , where \hat u_n is normal to the surface.

hint.p: Note an easier surface that has same number of field lines through it.

solution.p: Recall that a dot product also has a meaning in terms of the projection of vectors. For instance, \vec B\cdot\vec A is equal to the product of the magnitude |\vec B| and the projection of the vector \vec A in the the direction of the vector \vec B.

Here, the projection of the area denoted in the figure as PQRS in the direction of magnetic field is equal to the area at the base, viz. PQUT through which magnetic field lines pass perpendicularly. Therefore, the flux through PQRS is equal to the flux through PQUT.
\Phi_B = B_0\, a^2.

sidebyside.p:
Magnetic field of a current in a wire is inhomogeneous and varies over space. In the Cartesian coordinate system shown in , the magnetic field of the current I towards the positive z-axis in a long straight wire is given by
\vec B = \dfrac{\alpha}{x^2+y^2}\left(- y\hat u_x + x \hat u_y\right),

statement.p: where \alpha = \mu_0 I/2\pi. The magnetic field lines in teh figure are shown circulating about z axis.
Find the flux through surfaces (a) S_1, (b) S_2, and (c) S_3 shown in .

solution.title: (a)
solution.p: Since the magnetic field varies over an area, we will think in terms of area element dA of each surface.
(a) The normal \hat u_n to surface S_1 is along the z-axis. Therefore, the dot product of \vec B with \hat u_n will vanish, which makes the flux through S_1 zero.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) The normal \hat u_n to surface S_2 along the x-axis, giving \hat u_n = + \hat u_x or \hat u_n = - \hat u_x. Due to this ambguity in normal direction, we will get two answers. The area element on S_2 in the yz-plane is
d\vec A = \pm dydz \hat u_x.
The surface S_2 has x=0. The magnetic flux through S_2 will be given by the following integral based on the general formula.
\Phi_B \amp = \iint \vec B\cdot d\vec A \amp = \mp\alpha\int_{y=b_1}^{y=b_2}\int_{z=c_1}^{z=c_2}\left[ \dfrac{y}{x^2+y^2}\right] _{x=0}dydz \amp = \mp\alpha \left(c_2-c_1 \right) \ln{\left(\dfrac{b_2}{b_1}\right)}

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) A similar calculation as part (b) will give the following two answers for the magnetic flux through S_3.
\Phi_B = \pm\alpha \left(c_2-c_1 \right) \ln{\left(\dfrac{a_2}{a_1}\right)}
